entry.title: How to Take SAP‚Äôs New Performance-Based Certification Exams
entry.content:
Beginning in November 2025, SAP updated parts of its certification program by introducing scenario-based assessments exams. These exams replace the traditional proctored, multiple-choice format and are designed to better reflect real-world use cases.

In this post, I walk you through what has changed, how the new exam formats work, what to expect from AI-assisted and expert-reviewed assessments, and what this means for certification renewal‚Äîbased on my own experience retaking the SAP BTP Solution Architect exam.

Some certifications are now available only through this new approach like:

With this new format, there is less focus on memorizing detailed information. Instead, candidates demonstrate their knowledge by solving practical scenarios. You may complete tasks using AI-assisted tools or submit video-based responses that are reviewed by SAP experts later.

 You can explore available certifications by logging into SAP Learning at https://learning.sap.com and navigating to the Get Certified section.

To identify the exam format, click on the exam you are interested in. On the above right side of the exam page, the presence of ‚ÄúSchedule Exam‚Äù indicates that the exam is delivered through a third-party proctoring service:

If after clicking on the exam you see "Go to Certification Exam" on the top right ,it is on new scenario-based/system-based :

According to the SAP latest announcement, all SAP exams (by the end of March 2026) will be switched to this self-managed new performance-based exam.

If you choose the AI option with this new approach, the results are reviewed automatically in real time right after your submission. You can see your failure or success immediately. If you fail, you will receive the detailed analysis of your response by AI which can help you with your next exam try.

If you choose to submit videos, it will be scored by experts within 10 business days.

This analyzing session will not be available to you in your next log on, please make sure to review that before missing that session to help you to focus on your weakness for your next same exam attempt.

How real skills are used in scenario based

Practical

Certification exams mimic real tasks, such as configuring real SAP systems, building processes, coding, or delivering SAP solutions based on a case study.

Open book

Leverage all kinds of resources to complete the exams, just as you would on an actual SAP project. 

AI-enabled

Access AI support, such as SAP Joule for Consultants or any other AI Large Language Models (LLMs).

System-based assessment

Learners have the opportunity to complete practical tasks in time-limited SAP system simulations, testing their ability to perform specific tasks or operations.

Scenario-based assessment

Learners engage in time-limited role-play with an AI avatar, delivering SAP solutions, advising on architecture, and performing simulations.

A subscription to SAP Learning Hub includes 4 SAP certification exam attempts in one year or you can buy certification attempts (LINK).

At the time of writing this blog, to renew a certification for an additional year, you must have an active SAP Learning Hub subscription to complete the required renewal assessment:

If your certification is still valid, the renewal process does not require taking a performance-based or scenario-based exam. This exam formats apply only when pursuing a new certification, provided that the certification has already transitioned to the new scenario-based or practical exam approach.

Recently I decided to retake SAP BTP Solution Architect rather than renew through SAP leaning Hub assessment to help me to write this post.

New Certification approach with no proctor

Scenario based Steps:

  1. Start the Exam
  2. Choose your method (AI or Video record)
  3. Complete Tasks
  4. Submit &Confirm

System based steps:

  1. Find your exam in SAP Learning
  2. Hands-On Practice
  3. Schedule your exam
  4. Do System Check and wait for the day the schedule starts

Here I walk you through high level steps for BTP Solution Architect scenario-based exam:

First, you find your desired Exam page and click on the link:

https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-professional-solution-architect-sap-btp

Next you choose ‚ÄúGo to Certification Exam‚Äù:

Then, you see the screen below and after clicking the box for ‚ÄúTerms and Conditions‚Äù you can hit ‚Äústart Certification Exam‚Äù that will use one of your exam attempts credits and you have 24 hours to do the exam, or you lose one of your exams attempts credits:

As shown above, you have up to four exam attempts within a one-year period to achieve certification. If all four attempts are unsuccessful for that exam, you must wait 12 months before retaking the same exam.

Next, you will see the page below, which I chose AI for my Role-play then click on ‚ÄúAgree and get Started‚Äù:

Then you see the next screen and after allowing your camera, you will be able to start the exam by clicking on Start button:

Important note

Once you start the scenario-based exam session, the assessment typically takes around 20‚Äì30 minutes and is conducted through an AI-powered chat experience using Yoodli technology. Before clicking on Start button, it is strongly recommended that you thoroughly review the case study provided as part of the exam and prepare your solution in advance, for example in a notepad or word document, which you can reference during the AI role-play conversation.
You can use the pause button, it will stop the AI roleplay interaction, but the exam timer will continue to run. Be mindful of your remaining time before resuming the exercise. If you can't find the case study the pause may come handy to check to find the scenario or missing or even review again and then continue the AI session.
If you don‚Äôt pass a scenario-based assessment and still have time remaining, you can retake the exam right away, and it will count as a single exam attempt.

This exam uses Yoodli technology and does not require any software installation. If you would like to familiarize yourself with the format, you can create a free account at https://yoodli.ai/ and practice using sample role-play scenarios.

During the exam, an interactive chat window will appear, allowing you to follow the conversation and view a live transcript of the AI avatar‚Äôs responses.

Areas Where There Is Still Room for Improvement

While this new exam approach is a positive step forward, there are still areas that could benefit from further refinement. In particular, it would help to ensure that participants clearly understand the scenario or practice environment (especially for the scenario to be easily available in the session) and readily find sufficient time to review the requirements and prepare their responses before starting the session.

Compared to traditional proctored exams, there are also open questions around identity verification. It is not yet clear how this new format consistently confirms that the individual completing the assessment is the same person who registered for the exam.

In addition, with the new exam approach, candidates do not currently receive an automatic email notification showing pass or fail status, scores, or a detailed performance analysis.

Hopefully, the SAP certification team will continue refining this model so it better aligns with the rigor and value traditionally associated with proctored exams in these areas.

entry.title: Why Vectorized Master Data is Critical for AI on SAP ECC and S/4HANA
entry.content:
Why Most AI Agents Fail with SAP Data

AI Agents are rapidly becoming part of enterprise landscapes, and SAP ECC and S/4HANA are obvious targets for automation. However, what we see in the market today is concerning.

Most agentic solutions attempt to consume SAP data through custom coding. This approach creates three major problems:

  1. High development and maintenance costs

  2. Multiple, inefficient calls to the SAP backend

  3. Mass data extraction, where AI Agents pull entire tables just to find a few relevant records

In many of the solutions we reviewed, including agentic SDKs integrations such as Joule, n8n, ChatGPT, and Claude, AI Agents frequently fail, time out, or request all records from SAP ERP systems with minimal filtering. This is inefficient, risky, and completely unnecessary.

At Skybuffer AI, we believe there is a better way.

The Foundation: Preparing SAP Data for AI Consumption

Data preparation is the key to successful AI-driven automation. While topics like data silos and data quality are well known, they cannot be fully solved overnight. Instead of fighting this reality, Skybuffer AI introduces a simple and reliable data layer that AI Agents can consume efficiently.

Skybuffer AI uses SAP master data vectorization to enable fast, accurate access to SAP ECC and S/4HANA data from agentic workflows. Any SAP master data table, including views and CDS views, can be vectorized and materialized using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).

Key capabilities include:

  • Support for full and delta loads

  • Near real-time synchronization with SAP

  • A scalable, AI-ready representation of SAP master data

 Pic. 1 Skybuffer AI ‚Äì SAP Data Vectorization Configuration

Performance at Enterprise Scale

A common concern is performance. Vectorizing SAP master data row by row would indeed be slow, if done sequentially.

Skybuffer AI solves this with parallel embedding execution, allowing vectorization at enterprise scale. On servers with 8 GPUs, Skybuffer AI can process up to 1 million records in 30 minutes. That is scalable in case even faster vectorization solution is needed.

More importantly, once initial vectorization is complete, a self-healing delta mechanism ensures that only new or changed records are processed. This keeps the data current without impacting performance.

Business Value: Why This Approach Matters

The benefits are immediate and measurable:

  • No coding for intelligent master data search

  • No multiple calls to SAP backend systems

  • No full-table reads triggered by AI Agents

  • Faster, more reliable AI-driven processes

Consider a real-world scenario:
A vendor invoice arrives by email.

Pic. 2 Real Consumption-Based Invoice Example

The AI Agent reads the email and attachment, extracts the vendor name exactly as written on the invoice, and needs the corresponding SAP vendor number. Instead of querying SAP repeatedly or scanning entire tables, the Agent performs one single RAG search against vectorized SAP master data.

Within milliseconds, the correct vendor record is returned. It is accurate, up to date, and ready for posting in SAP.

Pic. 3 Skybuffer AI ‚Äì Fast and Reliable SAP Data Search Using Data Vectorization

No coding. No overload. No hallucinations.

Applicable Across Many SAP Use Cases

The same approach works seamlessly across multiple scenarios, including:

  • Finding SAP users or business objects by name, email address, or other attributes

  • Creating Sales Orders in SAP from customer Purchase Orders

  • Resolving customer and material master data automatically

  • Creating Bills of Materials and routings from Excel files managed by R&D teams

  • Posting Service Entry Sheets

  • Rapidly enabling new use cases by simply nominating tables for vectorization

If the data exists in SAP, it can be prepared for AI consumption.

Built-In Authorization and Security

Security is not an afterthought.

Skybuffer AI applies the same concept used in AI assistants for Teams, Copilot, and Joule, so vectorized data accessed by users with an additional safeguard. Once the AI Agent selects relevant records via RAG, Skybuffer AI retrieves those records directly from SAP using SSO within the active conversation session, before providing data to the user.

This ensures:

  • Users only see data they are authorized to access in SAP

  • Vectorized data never bypasses SAP authorization rules

  • Enterprise-grade compliance and governance

Seamless Integration with Existing AI Agents

Already running AI Agents and just need access to SAP data?

Skybuffer AI provides an MCP Server, allowing your existing agentic solutions to consume vectorized SAP data without replacing your current platform. This makes Skybuffer AI an enabler, not a disruptor.

 Pic. 4 Skybuffer AI ‚Äì MCP Server for Integration with Agentic SDK

Flexible Deployment: Cloud or On-Premise

Skybuffer AI is built on SAP HANA and can be deployed:

  • On-premise within your own infrastructure

  • In your SAP BTP tenant

A modern SAP UI5 user interface ensures an intuitive and productive user experience for both IT and business users.

Conclusion

SAP ECC and S/4HANA master data vectorization is the missing link between SAP and AI Agents.

With Skybuffer AI, enterprises can:

  • Eliminate coding

  • Avoid hallucinations

  • Reduce SAP backend load

  • Enable fast, secure, and reliable AI-driven processes

This is how SAP data becomes truly AI-ready.

As many customers adopt SAP Business Suite‚Äîa comprehensive set of integrated solutions combining Cloud ERP with Line of Business (LOB) applications, integration becomes a critical architectural pillar for delivering seamless, end-to-end business processes and unlocking the full potential of the SAP Business Suite.  
 
Typically, integration requires an extensive review of documentation, identification of all relevant components and entities, system landscape, creation of a detailed integration plan and the engagement of the appropriate subject matter experts with multiple reiterations. Altogether, these steps make integration a complex and time-consuming process. 

To address this, the Cloud Integration Automation service creates one consolidated guided workflow that orchestrates every step across the entire integration process. 

While the Cloud Integration Automation Service supports both public and private cloud scenarios, this blog focuses on providing an in-depth look at the public cloud scenarios available and how they can be utilized to accelerate your cloud adoption journey. 

Cloud Integration Automation service: Introduction 

Cloud Integration Automation service is an SAP BTP based integration application that comes with no additional cost that generates guided workflow to integrate SAP cloud solutions to on-premises and other SAP cloud solutions. The guided workflow contains automated tasks and instructions for manual tasks to enable an easy and quick integration configuration.

  • Integrated parameter management

Cloud Integration Automation service: Guided workflow 

Upon subscribing to and utilizing the Cloud Integration Automation service for any supported integration scenario, the application generates a guided workflow that includes all the necessary tasks to complete the integration

  • Fetch the underlying integration landscape  
  • Offers role-based implementation of each task 
  • Provides automated tasks 
  • Provides step by step manual instructions

entry.title: My highlights of the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release
entry.content:
Welcome to 2026 and welcome to my SAP Cloud ERP 2602 product release highlights! This blog post guides you through the key improvements of the 2602 release of SAP Cloud ERP, focusing on how they support customers in running and evolving their core business processes. And it was again not easy to decide what to declare as highlights amongst the large number of innovations delivered. It's our 34th major release over the years, and I have collected an interesting range across functional, foundational and user experience capabilities. And of course, the AI journey continues to boost both well-known and new ERP processes to a new levels. We're all in on AI.

I wish the team would have granted me more space to talk you through all innovation shipped with the 2602 release , take this blog post as an appetizer for our team‚Äôs deep dive blogs per line of business. Prefer video over text? Take a look at my product update video, where my digital twin guides you through the key highlights. 

 

A new operating model for integrated business processes 

With the first release of 2026, we walk the talk of our SAP Business Suite and introduce a range of SAP-managed Integrated Business Processes, removing the complexity of integrating and monitoring multiple cloud solutions from our customer's and partner's activity list. We have carefully listened to your wishes and SAP delivers co-provisioning, functional and technical integration, including lifecycle management, allowing these activities to move in the background while customers focus on their core business. By shifting responsibility for aligned system provisioning, functional and technical integration, and lifecycle management from customers to SAP, we reduce complexity behind the scenes and enables a more seamless suite experience.

* Click here to access the links mentioned in the slide above

As an initial step, release 2602 delivers SAP-managed integration for two critical end-to-end processes as part of an Early Adopter Care (EAC) program. In Workforce Management, SAP provides SAP-managed provisioning and integration between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, supporting a streamlined Recruit-to-Retire process with consistent employee and financial data from day one. For Operational Procurement, integrated processes across SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Ariba Buying, and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management simplify Procure-to-Pay activities and support a more unified procurement landscape.

These capabilities are enabled by blueprint-based provisioning, which changes how solution instances are deployed, integrated, and managed across the run phase. Instead of manual setup, customers can activate selective solutions or in the future complete suites that are provisioned and come already fully integrated together. Guided by a new suite experience in SAP for Me and based on SAP landscape modeling best practices, SAP applies a desired-state-based reconciliation to ensure transparency, consistency, and long-term stability across the application landscape.

 

AI innovations

SAP Joule for Consultants: Practical enhancements for your everyday project work

With this first release of year 2026, SAP Joule for Consultants continues to mature as a day-to-day companion for project focused workers, offering efficient access to trusted content, better transparency, and smoother workflows ‚Äì on demand. A new SAP Joule for Consultants console brings ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs New‚Äô release notes, an integrated prompt library, and, where relevant, administrative insights such as usage metrics and system settings into one central entry point, helping teams stay aligned with current innovations.

 

 

Joule now also surfaces SAP Notes and SAP Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs) directly within conversations, based on existing customer entitlements. This allows consultants to reference validated SAP guidance without leaving their context, while administrators retain control through standard s-user assignments. Usability improvements further support efficient work: Quick links simplify navigation across Joule features, the conversation character limit has been increased to 10,000 characters to accommodate larger inputs such as code or detailed scenarios, and public SAP content sources have been refreshed and expanded.

Enhanced citation visibility improves transparency by clearly indicating the origin of information, including public web sources when applicable.

 

Finally, the initial ingestion of SAP Signavio Process Navigator reference content lays the groundwork for more architecture-aware guidance in future releases.

 

Finance

Accounting Accruals Agent (beta)

In the dynamic landscape of financial management, the introduction of the beta version of Accounting Accruals Agent marks a thoughtful stride towards empowering finance professionals with innovative tools tailored for efficiency. This intelligent agent draws from AI-driven capabilities to meticulously craft accrual proposals, transforming the traditionally labor-intensive process into a streamlined operation. By analyzing accounting policy documents, sifting through historical data, and executing precise calculations, this agent reduces the substantial time accountants typically spend during period-end accruals. The newfound simplicity in the ‚ÄòManage Accrual Proposals‚Äô app not only enhances the speed of reviewing and posting proposals but also offers detailed, AI-backed explanations for each calculated entry. This ensures that general ledger accountants gain not just time but also trust in AI‚Äôs role in augmenting their decision-making processes, thereby enabling a smoother and more efficient period-end close. This feature is going to be made generally available in SAP Cloud ERP 2602.

 

SAP User Experience

AI-assisted task automation (beta)

In everyday work, many tasks in SAP Cloud ERP follow the same patterns: Reviewing data, triggering follow-up steps, or keeping processes moving. With AI-assisted task automation, SAP introduces smart helpers that support users exactly in these moments. Built with generative AI and embedded directly in My Home, these helpers can take over routine steps within SAP applications while keeping users in control whenever decisions or data changes are required. Instead of replacing human judgement, the focus is on reducing manual effort and helping users progress through their tasks more smoothly. Over time, this creates a more natural way of working with automation, one that adapts to real user needs and daily workflows. Customers interested in shaping this capability early can join the beta program to explore the feature and provide feedback that will influence future AI-driven experiences in SAP Cloud ERP.

Check out this link to sign up for the beta testing and shape the future of AI innovations: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#campaign/4086 

 

Retail

Assortment module management 

Many non-retail industries integrate retail capabilities into their ERP systems to enhance customer services and collaboration, even in B2B. Most organizations today are expected to react faster to changing customer expectations while keeping operations efficient and scalable. This requires tools that simplify everyday work for planners and merchandisers, reduce operational friction, and make it easier to translate data and insights into action. In this context, intelligent assistance within core retail processes becomes increasingly important, especially where decisions around assortments directly influence customer experience and business outcomes.

In the area of Retail, Joule‚Äôs integration into assortment module management supports planners by making common tasks more accessible and less time-consuming. Instead of navigating multiple screens, users can rely on natural language interactions to create, update, or terminate assortments directly within the application. This reduces dependency on deep technical knowledge and helps teams complete routine tasks with greater confidence and efficiency. As a result, merchandising and category managers can spend less time on operational steps and more time focusing on assortment strategy and customer-centric planning.

For more information, please consult SAP Help Portal.

 

Asset Management

Maintenance notification creation and screening with Joule

In Asset Management, keeping maintenance processes running smoothly depends on timely and accurate notifications, often created under time pressure and by users outside of specialized maintenance roles. With Joule integrated into the maintenance notification process in SAP Cloud ERP, creating and screening notifications becomes more straightforward and accessible. Users can describe an issue in natural language and capture key details such as the technical object, priority, and description without navigating complex transaction flows. Moreover, users can access notifications in the ‚ÄòManage Maintenance Notification‚Äô SAP Fiori app (F5777), enabling quick acceptance and conversion into maintenance orders within a single conversational context. As a result, operators spend less time on documentation, while maintenance teams and managers benefit from clearer, more consistent information to plan and execute maintenance activities effectively.

 

SAP Activate innovations

SAP Activate introduces several innovations for the 2602 release, starting with a dedicated activation and implementation guidance for customers adopting SAP-managed integrations in the Early Adopter Care program, mentioned earlier.

Customers implementing SAP Cloud ERP will continue to benefit from easier access to implementation information with Joule, which is embedded in the ‚ÄôRoadmap Viewer‚Äô application on SAP for Me. Additionally, implementation teams can access up-to-date implementation guidance in nine languages: Chinese, English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, and Spanish. Change your language preferences in SAP for Me to view content in another language.

Customers conducting the upgrade to the 2602 release can leverage the lean upgrade roadmap in the ‚ÄòRoadmap Viewer‚Äô app or in SAP Cloud ALM to guide their team through the upgrade and post-upgrade activities. 

 

SAP Cloud ALM updates

In transformation projects, teams often invest a lot of time turning workshop outcomes, documents, and process discussions into structured requirements and test assets. With the latest updates in SAP Cloud ALM, this work becomes more streamlined across the project lifecycle. AI-assisted  requirements generation helps teams create initial requirements automatically based on Fit-to-Standard workshop transcripts, solution processes, and other project documentation, giving project members a solid starting point that can be reviewed and refined instead of built from scratch.

As project scopes evolve, requirements can now be moved easily between projects, supporting reuse and reducing duplication.

 

 Further enhancements focus on governance and test preparation.

New APIs for manual test cases, process hierarchies, and features make it easier to integrate SAP Cloud ALM into existing tool landscapes and automate project reporting or oversight. All SAP Cloud ALM APIs can be found on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

During test preparation, teams can now define where screenshots are required as test evidence, improving transparency and auditability during execution.

 

Updates to release assessment and scope dependency

Smarter upgrades in SAP Cloud ERP require a clear understanding of customer¬¥s individually relevant applications and scope items. The release assessment and scope dependency (RASD) tool continues to evolve, incorporating customer feedback to make impact analysis more transparent and easier to work with. Recent updates simplify how assessment results are shared, allowing users to download content across all tiles, or selected ones, into a single ZIP file with structured Excel outputs that can be reviewed, filtered, and discussed across distributed project teams.

Beyond usability improvements, RASD now provides more precise guidance for upgrade decisions. The introduction of a successor view helps identify recommended follow-on apps, supporting smoother transition planning.

In addition, enhanced views in the personalized 'What‚Äôs New Viewer' clearly differentiate between activated, used, and impacted scope items, helping teams focus on what truly matters in their system.

Together, these enhancements support more informed discussions, reduce uncertainty during release preparation, and help teams approach upgrades with greater clarity and confidence.

 

Other innovations across various LoBs

Supply Chain Management ‚Äì Warehouse management

Interface to warehouse automation systems for efficiently processing warehouse orders

In the evolving landscape of warehouse management, the integration of warehouse automation systems is set to significantly enhance operational efficiency. By seamlessly distributing warehouse orders to automated subsystems, businesses can ensure smooth and coordinated task execution. This interface not only sends out orders but also receives confirmations of warehouse tasks, creating a continuous feedback loop that ensures transparency and efficiency. Such integration significantly cuts down manual intervention, allowing for a more streamlined process that minimizes errors and enhances productivity. The main advantage lies in the ability to process warehouse orders more efficiently, capitalizing on automation to handle tasks that were once labor-intensive. This means warehouse operations can maintain a high level of accuracy while handling greater volumes, ultimately enhancing the overall supply chain performance and reliability.

 

 

Manufacturing

Production order combination enablement

In the Manufacturing line of business, we are happy to introduce production order combination enablement, which offers a practical solution to streamline operations and enhance efficiency. By merging identical operations from different production orders into a single consolidated order, manufacturers can optimize their processes right from the ‚ÄòManage Production Orders‚Äô app. This functionality allows for the creation, maintenance, and confirmation of combined orders, which in turn supports effective cost distribution and settlement through new event-based costing. By reducing setup times and overhead charges, this approach not only increases production throughput but also achieves considerable cost savings. This feature empowers manufacturers to focus their efforts on boosting output while maintaining a keen eye on cost efficiency, creating a more agile and responsive production environment.

 

Professional Services

Intercompany cost allocations reconciliation review booklet

In the Professional Services domain, the enhancement of the ‚ÄòIntercompany Review Booklet‚Äô app offers a significant boost in transparency and traceability for intercompany cost allocations. By displaying the complete end-to-end document flow, this app helps reconcile management accounting postings with billing and accounts receivable documents. This comprehensive view is invaluable during closing procedures, as it allows businesses to ensure their data's completeness by clearly identifying services and expenses that have been billed, are partially billed, or remain unbilled. Furthermore, the app provides audit-relevant information on billed intercompany services, offering businesses the assurance and documentation needed for clear internal and external audits. This capability aids organizations in maintaining robust financial processes while enhancing their ability to track and manage intercompany transactions efficiently. Starting with release 2602, the report will include an enhanced breakdown of billed entries, tracing them all the way to the receiver FI journal entry/affiliated expenses.  

 

Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP

In the domain of Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management, enhancing the integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP was one of the items discussed and designed in our customer product councils. This innovation facilitates seamless synchronization of project plan data between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Project and Resource Management, enabling a more cohesive project management experience. Users can manually trigger updates to project dates in SAP Cloud ERP, ensuring that information remains current and accurate. Furthermore, the automated bi-directional synchronization of project plan data significantly reduces the manual effort involved in data maintenance, allowing teams to focus on strategic initiatives. With greater scope control and improved integration, organizations can enjoy comprehensive visibility of critical information across different solutions, thus enhancing data quality and operational efficiency. This development empowers project managers with the tools needed to effectively monitor and control project progress, fostering better decision-making and resource allocation throughout the project lifecycle.

 

Summary

I hope this overview of the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release highlights has provided helpful insights into the latest updates and enhancements as well as excitement for the upgrade. As SAP Cloud ERP continues to evolve, these innovations aim to support more efficient processes, clearer guidance, and a smoother experience across implementations and upgrades.

Let me know which innovation stands out most to you and what your personal highlights from this release are: Feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Let‚Äôs keep advancing together‚Äîtowards a smarter, more connected cloud ERP future.

Yours,

entry.title: High Impact SAP Data Objects to Clean for an S/4HANA Selective Transition from ECC
entry.content:
*Views Expressed here are my own and doesn't represent any entity.

Introduction

Moving from SAP ECC to S/4HANA using a Selective Data Transition is not just a technical system conversion,it is a data transformation journey. While selective carve outs allow organizations to migrate only relevant organizational units, time slices, or data sets, poor data quality can jeopardize the entire S/4HANA transformation.S/4HANA‚Äôs simplified data model, stricter checks, and real-time processing mean that legacy inconsistencies tolerated in ECC will cause errors, functional gaps, or performance issues in S/4HANA.

This blog outlines the SAP data objects that require mandatory data cleaning before a selective S/4HANA migration, along with practical examples and rationale for each.

Why Data Cleaning Is Mandatory in a Selective Transition

In a selective approach:

  • Only chosen company codes, plants, or years are migrated

  • Historical inconsistencies become more visible

  • Data is restructured, not simply converted

S/4HANA:

  • Enforces business partner (BP) as a single master

  • Removes many legacy tables

  • Uses real-time reconciliation

  • Requires consistent master and transactional data

Without cleaning, you risk:

  • Migration failures

  • Reconciliation mismatches

  • Broken business processes

  • Delayed go-lives

1. Business Partner (Customer & Vendor)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Duplicate customers/vendors

  • Inconsistent master data across company codes

  • Missing mandatory fields (address, tax, bank details)

  • Vendors acting as customers (and vice versa)

ECC Example

  • Vendor 100045 exists for AP

  • Customer 200078 exists for AR

  • Same legal entity, different tax IDs and addresses

Why This Is Mandatory

In S/4HANA:

  • Customers and Vendors are merged into Business Partner

  • Roles (Customer, Supplier) are assigned to a single BP number

  • Inconsistent data causes CVI (Customer Vendor Integration) errors

Rationale

Selective transitions often migrate only certain company codes, making duplicates harder to reconcile post-migration. Cleaning ensures:

  • Smooth BP conversion

  • Accurate AR/AP reporting

  • Compliance with S/4 data model

2. Material Master Data

What Needs Cleaning

  • Obsolete or unused materials

  • Incomplete views (MM, SD, PP)

  • Invalid units of measure

  • Duplicate material numbers

ECC Example

  • Material created but never used in 8 years

  • Sales view missing for materials with open SD history

  • Base UoM inconsistent with alternative UoM

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Performs real-time MRP

  • Uses simplified inventory tables (MATDOC)

  • Enforces stricter checks on material consistency

Rationale

Migrating unused or inconsistent materials:

  • Increases migration volume

  • Slows performance

  • Causes MRP and ATP errors

Selective transitions benefit most by reducing material footprint.

3. Chart of Accounts & G/L Accounts

What Needs Cleaning

  • Blocked or unused G/L accounts

  • Accounts without proper account type

  • Inconsistent descriptions across company codes

  • Legacy reconciliation accounts

ECC Example

  • G/L 799999 created for testing, never used

  • Same G/L has different names in different company codes

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Introduces Universal Journal (ACDOCA)

  • FI and CO are merged

  • Reconciliation accounts behave differently

Rationale

Dirty G/L data leads to:

  • Conversion errors

  • Financial reconciliation issues

  • Incorrect financial statements

In selective transitions, only active and relevant accounts should be migrated.

4. Open Financial Transactions (AR/AP)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Cleared documents not properly closed

  • Open items with incorrect statuses

  • Residual items with zero balance

  • Old parked documents

ECC Example

  • Invoice marked as open but cleared manually

  • Zero-balance open items still flagged as open

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Performs real-time reconciliation

  • No longer tolerates technical inconsistencies

  • Universal Journal requires exact balances

Rationale

Open AR/AP items are always migrated in selective scenarios. Incorrect open items cause:

  • Balance mismatches

  • Failed migrations

  • Post-go-live reconciliation chaos

5. Asset Accounting (FI-AA)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Assets without acquisition values

  • Assets without depreciation areas

  • Retired assets still marked as active

  • Incomplete asset master records

ECC Example

  • Asset created but never capitalized

  • Depreciation area missing for a company code

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Uses New Asset Accounting only

  • Fully integrated into Universal Journal

  • Legacy asset inconsistencies cannot be converted

Rationale

Selective transitions often migrate only active assets. Cleaning ensures:

  • Correct depreciation

  • Accurate asset balances

  • Compliance with S/4 FI-AA model

6. Open Logistics Transactions

What Needs Cleaning

  • Open purchase orders with no activity

  • Incomplete deliveries

  • Open production orders never closed

  • Inconsistent goods movements

ECC Example

  • PO created 6 years ago, no GR, no IR

  • Production order technically complete but not closed

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Uses MATDOC for inventory

  • Enforces strict document flow

  • Real-time stock valuation

Rationale

Open logistics documents are technically migrated, not recreated. Dirty data causes:

  • Stock inconsistencies

  • Migration failures

  • Incorrect inventory valuation

7. Customizing and Organizational Data

What Needs Cleaning

  • Unused plants, storage locations

  • Inactive company codes

  • Invalid assignments (plant to company code)

  • Legacy controlling areas

ECC Example

  • Plant exists but no postings in 10 years

  • Company code included but not in scope

Why This Is Mandatory

Selective transitions rely on precise scoping. Invalid org data:

  • Complicates data slicing

  • Causes migration logic conflicts

  • Increases testing effort

Rationale

Clean org structures ensure:

  • Correct selective extraction

  • Lean S/4 system

  • Lower total cost of ownership

8. Custom Code & Z-Objects (Indirect Data Impact)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Z-tables with obsolete data

  • Custom programs using removed tables

  • Hard-coded company codes or years

ECC Example

  • Z-table referencing BKPF/BSEG directly

  • Custom report using VBFA incorrectly

Why This Is Mandatory

While not migrated as data:

  • Custom code processes migrated data

  • Dirty Z-data can break business processes

Rationale

Selective data migration often includes selective Z-data. Cleaning avoids:

  • Runtime errors

  • Incorrect reporting

  • Post-go-live defects

Understand your Business "WHY" for DATA CLEARLY

A Selective S/4HANA transition magnifies data quality issues because only parts of the system are migrated. S/4HANA‚Äôs simplified architecture does not tolerate inconsistencies that ECC allowed for decades.

Mandatory Data Cleaning Ensures:

  • Successful migration runs

  • Accurate financial reconciliation

  • Stable business processes

  • Long-term S/4HANA performance

Key Takeaway:

Data cleansing is not a technical task‚Äîit is a business transformation enabler.

entry.title: SAP ECC vs S/4HANA Integration Capabilities: A Practical Guide for Integration Architects
entry.content:
SAP System Exposure: The Complete Integration Capability Guide for ECC & S/4HANA

1. INTRODUCTION

When I'm asked to integrate an external system with SAP, the first question isn't "which tool should I use?" It's "what can SAP actually expose?"

After few years working across SAP ECC and S/4HANA landscapes with Integration Suite, I've learned that understanding what's available in your SAP system is just as critical as knowing how to integrate it. Yet most integration guides skip this foundation and jump straight to implementation.

This is the reference guide, it maps every integration capability available in SAP ECC and S/4HANA On-Premises systems, explains when to use each protocol, and provides the checklists you need to prepare your systems for Integration Suite connectivity.

What You'll Learn:

  • Complete inventory of integration capabilities in ECC vs. S/4HANA
  • RFC/BAPI, IDoc, OData, SOAP, and file interface fundamentals
  • Protocol comparison matrix with use case recommendations.
  • System preparation checklists for production readiness
  • Integration architecture patterns
  • Decision framework for choosing the right protocol.

Who This Is For:

  • Integration consultants working with SAP landscapes.
  • Solution architects designing SAP integrations.
  • Developers building connections to SAP systems.
  • Functional consultants exploring integration possibilities.
  • Anyone planning Integration Suite implementations.

Let's start with what SAP can actually give us.

 

2. SAP ECC INTEGRATION CAPABILITIES

SAP ECC has been the backbone of enterprise operations for decades. While it lacks some modern REST/OData capabilities, it provides robust, battle-tested integration interfaces that still power thousands of integrations today.

2.1 RFC (Remote Function Call) & BAPIs

RFC is SAP's proprietary protocol for synchronous communication between systems. BAPIs (Business Application Programming Interfaces) are standardized RFCs that provide access to SAP business objects and processes.

Key Characteristics:

  • Synchronous: Call and wait for response
  • Transactional: Can commit or rollback
  • Type-safe: Strongly typed parameters.
  • Widely available: Broad range of reusable standard BAPIs in ECC

Common BAPIs You'll Use:

BAPI Name

Purpose

Use Case

BAPI_PO_CREATE1

Create Purchase Order

External procurement systems posting POs

BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE

Post Goods Movement

Warehouse systems updating inventory

BAPI_MATERIAL_GETDETAIL

Get Material Master

E-commerce platforms fetching product data

BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST

Post Financial Document

External systems creating FI documents

BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2

Create Sales Order

CRM systems posting orders to SAP

BAPI_CUSTOMER_GETDETAIL

Get Customer Master

External apps accessing customer data

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction SE37 (Function Builder)
  • Discovery: Search pattern "BAPI_*"
  • Testing: SE37 ‚Üí Test/Execute
  • Authentication: RFC destination in SM59

When to Use RFCs/BAPIs:

Use When:

  • You need real-time, synchronous responses
  • Transaction integrity is critical (commit/rollback)
  • Complex business logic required
  • Creating or updating SAP documents
  • Reading data with complex selection criteria

Avoid When:

  • Processing large data volumes (use IDoc instead)
  • No immediate response needed (use IDoc/async)
  • Simple CRUD on standard entities (use OData in S/4HANA)
  • Performance is more important than transaction integrity.

 Integration Pattern:

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Purchase Order Creation from Web Portal

Business Context:
Manufacturing company has external procurement portal where buyers create purchase requests. Once approved, these need to become POs in SAP ECC instantly.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: Custom web portal (Node.js/React)
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • BAPI: BAPI_PO_CREATE1
  • Frequency: Real-time (on PR approval)
  • Volume: 50-100 POs per day

Process Flow:

2.2 IDoc (Intermediate Document)

IDoc (Intermediate Document) is SAP‚Äôs standard asynchronous integration mechanism.
It is designed for high-volume, reliable, loosely coupled data exchange between SAP and external systems.

An IDoc is:

  • Self-contained
  • Status-driven
  • Processed independently of user interaction

This makes IDocs ideal for batch integrations, master data replication, and guaranteed delivery scenarios.

Key Characteristics:

  • Asynchronous: Fire-and-forget or guaranteed delivery
  • Bulk-friendly: Efficient for large volumes
  • Loosely coupled: Systems don't need to be online simultaneously
  • Status-tracked: Built-in monitoring (WE02, WE05)

IDoc Structure:

Common IDoc Types:

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction WE30 (IDoc Type Development)
  • Partner Setup: WE20 (Partner Profiles)
  • Port Config: WE21 (Port Definition)
  • Testing: WE19 (Test Tool)
  • Monitoring: WE02 (IDoc Display), WE05 (IDoc List)
  • Triggering: Message Control, Change Pointers, IDOC_OUTPUT_* FMs

When to Use IDocs:

Use When:

  • High-volume data transfer (thousands of records)
  • Asynchronous processing acceptable
  • Standard SAP business documents (PO, Invoice, etc.)
  • Batch processing requirements.
  • Need for guaranteed delivery with retry.
  • Master data replication

Avoid When:

  • Real-time response required immediately
  • Complex transformations needed
  • Non-standard data structures
  • Simple CRUD operations (overkill)

Integration Patterns:

Outbound (ECC ‚Üí External):

Inbound (External ‚Üí ECC):

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Nightly Material Master Sync to Data Warehouse

Company needs to send all material master changes from ECC to external data warehouse every night for reporting and analytics.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: SAP ECC 6.0
  • Target: External Data Warehouse (Snowflake)
  • IDoc Type: MATMAS05
  • Frequency: Nightly batch (2 AM)
  • Volume: 5,000-10,000 materials per night

 End-to-End IDoc Asynchronous Integration Flow

  1. Material master records are created or updated in SAP ECC throughout the day (MM01/MM02).
  2. Change pointers capture only relevant delta changes for the MATMAS message type.
  3. At 2:00 AM, the BD21 batch job executes during off-peak hours.
  4. The system reads accumulated change pointers.
  5. A MATMAS05 IDoc is generated for each changed material.
  6. IDocs are sent via partner profile WAREHOUSE using an HTTP port.
  7. SAP CPI receives the IDoc XML through the IDoc adapter.
  8. CPI parses the hierarchical IDoc structure.
  9. Business data is transformed into a target JSON format.
  10. Records are grouped into batches of 1,000 for optimized processing.
  11. CPI posts each batch to the Snowflake bulk API.
  12. On success, IDocs are updated to status 53 (Posted).
  13. On failure, IDocs move to 51 (Error) and are retried in the next batch cycle.
  14. A consolidated processing report is emailed to the data team at 3:00 AM.

2.3 SOAP Web Services

SAP ECC exposes business functionality as SOAP-based web services using the Enterprise Services Repository (ESR).
These services are WSDL-driven, XML-based, and follow a strict request‚Äìresponse contract over HTTP/HTTPS.

SOAP services are widely used in legacy enterprise landscapes, especially where Java or .NET middleware already exists.

Key Characteristics:

  • Standards-based: WSDL, SOAP 1.1/1.2, WS-* standards
  • Synchronous: Request-response pattern
  • Platform-agnostic: Any SOAP client can consume
  • Structured: XSD-defined schemas

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction SOAMANAGER (Service Administration)
  • Development: SPROXY (Proxy Development)
  • Types:
    • Provider Services (ECC exposes to external)
    • Consumer Services (ECC consumes from external)

When to Use SOAP:

Use When:

  • External system requires SOAP/WSDL
  • Enterprise service repository already defined.
  • Need WS-Security features.
  • Cross-platform integration with Java/.NET systems

Avoid When:

  • Modern REST/JSON preferred (not natively supported in ECC)
  • Performance is critical (SOAP overhead)
  • Simple operations (BAPI or IDoc simpler)

Integration Pattern:

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Legacy Java Middleware Posting Financial Documents

Existing Java-based middleware system (10 years old) collects invoice data from multiple subsidiaries and needs to post consolidated financial documents to ECC.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: Java middleware (Spring Boot)
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • Service: FinancialDocumentCreate (Enterprise Service)
  • Frequency: Real-time as invoices arrive
  • Volume: 200-300 documents per day

Process Flow:

  1. Java app collects invoice from subsidiaries.
  2. Validates and enriches data.
  3. Builds SOAP XML per WSDL specification.
  4. Sends SOAP request to CPI endpoint.
  5. CPI routes to ECC SOAMANAGER
  6. Enterprise service validates structure.
  7. Calls backend BAPI for FI posting.
  8. Document posted, accounting entries created.
  9. Returns FI document number in SOAP response.
  10. Java app stores document number for reference.

2.4 File Interfaces

File interfaces are one of the oldest and most reliable integration mechanisms in SAP ECC, designed for scheduled, high-volume, non-real-time data exchange.
Data is exchanged using physical files that are picked up, processed, and archived in batch cycles.

This pattern is still widely used for:

  • Vendor uploads
  • Price lists
  • Mass master data changes
  • One-time or recurring migrations

File Formats:

  • Flat files (fixed width, delimited)
  • CSV/Excel
  • XML
  • Custom formats

Technical Approaches:

  • Output: Report programs, BDC, LSMW
  • Input: Batch Input (BDC), Direct Input, BAPI calls

When to Use Files:

Use When:

  • Batch processing windows.
  • Large data migrations
  • Legacy system integration
  • Offline scenarios

Avoid When:

  • Real-time requirements
  • Frequent small transactions
  • Complex error handling needs.

Example Scenario: Nightly Vendor Price Upload (CSV)

The procurement team receives daily price updates from multiple vendors.
Each vendor uploads a CSV file containing updated material prices, which must be reflected in SAP ECC before business hours.

Technical Setup

  • Source: Vendor SFTP servers
  • Integration Layer: SAP CPI
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • File Type: CSV
  • Schedule: Nightly (4:00 AM)
  • Volume: ~50 files, 10,000‚Äì15,000 records

Process Flow (Clear & Sequential)

  1. Vendors upload CSV price files to the SFTP server between 1:00‚Äì3:00 AM
  2. At 4:00 AM, SAP CPI scheduler triggers the batch job
  3. CPI connects to SFTP and downloads all available files
  4. For each file, CPI:
    • Identifies the vendor from the file name
    • Parses the CSV line by line
    • Validates mandatory fields and price values
  5. For each valid record:
    • CPI calls BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA
    • Updates the vendor price / info record
  6. Processing continues even if individual records fail
  7. CPI writes:
    • Success entries to the success log
    • Failed records to the error log with reason
  8. Processed files are archived to /archive
  9. A summary report is generated
  10. Email notification is sent to the procurement team

WHAT SAP ECC CANNOT DO (WITHOUT WORKAROUNDS)

ECC is powerful for traditional integration, but modern patterns require custom work. Understanding this shapes your architecture strategy.

NO NATIVE REST/ODATA APIS

ECC doesn't provide REST APIs out of the box. You can build them, but not easily:

Workaround Options:

  • NetWeaver Gateway add-on (SEGW)
  • ICF HTTP handlers (IF_HTTP_EXTENSION)
  • Custom ABAP REST wrappers
  • SOAP-to-REST via CPI

LIMITED EVENT-DRIVEN CAPABILITIES

ECC has event-like features, but not modern event streaming:

What You Get:

  • Change pointers (batch-oriented)
  • Workflow events (tightly coupled)
  • IDoc triggers (application-specific)

What You Don't Get:

  • Publish/subscribe architecture
  • Multiple independent subscribers
  • Event replay
  • True decoupling

Impact: Adding a new event consumer requires ECC configuration changes. Not cloud-native.

Why This Works:

  • ECC does what it's designed for: business logic.
  • CPI manages modern protocols, security, governance.
  • No custom code burden in ECC
  • Easy S/4HANA migration path

Strategic Guidance:

  • Use CPI for protocol translation.
  • Keep ECC focused on business processes.
  • Plan your S/4HANA path.

3. SAP S/4HANA ON-PREMISE INTEGRATION CAPABILITIES

S/4HANA builds on everything ECC provides and adds modern integration capabilities that change the game.

3.1 EVERYTHING ECC HAS, ENHANCED

RFCs/BAPIs:

  • All ECC BAPIs available
  • New S/4HANA-specific BAPIs
  • Better performance (HANA database)
  • CDS view consumption via RFCs

IDocs:

  • All ECC IDoc types
  • Improved processing speed
  • Better error handling
  • Enhanced monitoring

SOAP Services:

  • All enterprise services
  • Service adaptation framework
  • Better performance

3.2 ODATA SERVICES (THE GAME CHANGER)

OData is the REST-based protocol that makes SAP data accessible like modern APIs. This is what S/4HANA has that ECC doesn't, and it's transformative.OData introduces true RESTful APIs, designed for:

  • Web applications
  • Mobile apps
  • External developer consumption
  • Real-time queries

Why OData Matters

  • REST over HTTP
  • JSON-first
  • Queryable data access
  • Self-describing APIs

Key Characteristics:

  • RESTful: Standard HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE)
  • JSON/XML: Modern data formats
  • Query-capable: $filter, $select, $expand, $orderby, $top, $skip
  • Self-documenting: $metadata endpoint
  • Stateless: No session management needed

SAP Gateway Architecture:

 

Standard S/4HANA APIs (Examples):

API Service

Business Purpose

Key Entity Sets

API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV

Purchase Order lifecycle management

A_PurchaseOrder, A_PurchaseOrderItem

API_PRODUCT_SRV

Material / Product master data

A_Product, A_ProductDescription

API_SALES_ORDER_SRV

Sales order processing

A_SalesOrder, A_SalesOrderItem

API_BUSINESS_PARTNER

Unified business partner model

A_BusinessPartner, A_BPContactAddress

API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV

Inventory and stock levels

A_MaterialStock

Technical Details:

  • Service Registration: /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE
  • Testing: /IWFND/GW_CLIENT
  • Development: SEGW (Gateway Service Builder)
  • Monitoring: /IWFND/ERROR_LOG

OData Query Capabilities

Basic Read

GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseOrder

Filtering

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder

?$filter=DocumentDate ge datetime'2025-01-01'

 and PurchaseOrderType eq 'NB'

Selecting Specific Fields

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder

?$select=PurchaseOrder,Supplier,DocumentDate,TotalAmount

Expanding Navigation Properties

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder('4500000001')

?$expand=to_PurchaseOrderItem

Pagination

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder?$top=100&$skip=0

Response:

"__next": "...&$skiptoken=100"

Metadata Discovery

GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV/$metadata

Returns:

  • Entity sets
  • Properties
  • Associations

When to Use OData

Use When

  • Modern web or mobile applications
  • Real-time queries required
  • REST/JSON integration
  • Flexible query support needed

Avoid When

  • SAP ECC system
  • Complex transactional rollback required.
  • Bulk data transfer

EXAMPLE SCENARIO: Mobile Sales App Querying Products

Business Context:

Sales representatives use mobile app to check product availability, pricing, and specifications while visiting customers. Need instant access to product catalog with real-time stock levels.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: React Native mobile app
  • Target: S/4HANA On-Premise
  • API: API_PRODUCT_SRV, API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV
  • Frequency: Real-time as sales rep searches
  • Volume: 500-1,000 queries per day

Process Flow:

  1. Sales rep searches "Bearing" in mobile app
  2. App sends HTTP GET to CPI endpoint
  3. CPI forwards to S/4HANA Gateway
  4. Gateway routes to Data Provider Class
  5. DPC queries HANA database (ultra-fast)
  6. Returns matching products as JSON
  7. For each product, fetch stock level
  8. Combine product + stock data
  9. Response returns to mobile app
  10. Rep sees list: 15 products with prices and stock

3.3 CDS Views as Integration Endpoints

Core Data Services (CDS) views are HANA-optimized semantic data models defined in S/4HANA. They represent business entities and logic at the database level and can be exposed directly for integration.

CDS views can be:

  • Exposed as OData services via SAP Gateway
  • Consumed internally or externally via RFC-enabled function modules

Key Benefits

  • High performance: Logic is pushed down to the HANA database
  • Pre-aggregated data: Reduces processing in the application layer
  • Embedded business logic: Calculations, annotations, and semantics included
  • Rich relationships: Associations allow navigation across related entities

Process Flow

CDS View ‚Üí Gateway Service ‚Üí OData ‚Üí Integration Suite

3.4 SAP Business Events & Real-Time Integration

S/4HANA introduces native event-driven integration capabilities, allowing systems to react immediately to business changes instead of relying on batch jobs or polling.

Key enhancements include:

  • Standardized business event triggers
  • Improved change detection
  • Workflow-driven event publishing
  • Native integration with SAP Event Mesh

Event-Driven Integration Pattern

S/4HANA Business Event ‚Üí Event Mesh Topic ‚Üí Multiple Subscribers (CPI iFlows) ‚Üí External Systems

Typical Use Cases

  • Purchase order approved ‚Üí Notify procurement portal
  • Stock level falls below threshold ‚Üí Trigger replenishment
  • Sales order created ‚Üí Update CRM system
  • Invoice posted ‚Üí Notify payment or reporting systems

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Real-Time Stock Alerts to E-Commerce

E-commerce website needs instant notifications when product stock falls below threshold to display "Low Stock" warnings and trigger replenishment.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: S/4HANA On-Premises
  • Targets: E-commerce website, Replenishment system, Analytics dashboard
  • Event: Material.StockChanged
  • Frequency: Real-time (as goods movements occur)
  • Volume: 2,000-3,000 events per day

Step-by-Step Flow

  1. Goods Issue Posted
    • A goods issue is posted in S/4HANA using transaction MIGO.
  2. Stock Update in HANA
    • The stock quantity is immediately updated in the HANA database.
  3. Business Event Triggered
    • The system triggers the business event Material.StockChanged.
  4. Event Published
    • The event is published to SAP Event Mesh.
    • Topic: inventory/changes
  5. Parallel Event Consumption
    • Multiple systems subscribe to the same event and process it independently.

Subscriber A ‚Äì E-Commerce System

  • Receives the event through a CPI iFlow
  • Updates the product page inventory
  • Displays a ‚ÄúLow Stock‚Äù indicator (e.g., ‚ÄúOnly 75 left‚Äù)

Subscriber B ‚Äì Replenishment System

  • Evaluates stock against reorder threshold (100 units)
  • If below threshold:
    • Creates a Purchase Requisition
    • Notifies the purchasing team

Subscriber C ‚Äì Analytics Dashboard

  • Updates real-time inventory charts
  • Stores event data in the data warehouse for reporting
  1. Independent Processing
    • Each subscriber processes the event independently and in parallel.
  2. Acknowledgement
    • Each system sends an acknowledgement back to Event Mesh.

 

Events are published once and delivered to multiple consumers in parallel, without tight coupling.

3.5 What S/4HANA Adds Over ECC

S/4HANA builds on the proven integration capabilities of ECC and introduces modern, API-driven and event-based features that significantly expand what is possible in real-time and cloud-native landscapes.

Now that we understand what each system offers, let's look at how to choose the right protocol and see complete integration scenarios.

    • Protocol: REST ‚Üí RFC/BAPI

5. System Preparation Checklists

Before starting integration development, systems must be technically and operationally ready. The following checklists reflect production-grade prerequisites.

5.1 SAP ECC Preparation

6. INTEGRATION ARCHITECTURE OVERVIEW

Understanding how all pieces fit together:

Component Explanations

Cloud Connector

  • Provides a secure tunnel between SAP BTP and on-premise SAP systems
  • Eliminates the need for VPN connectivity
  • Enables resource-level access control
  • Supports audit logging for compliance and security monitoring

CPI Adapters

  • Enable protocol translation (RFC ‚Üî REST, IDoc ‚Üî JSON, SOAP ‚Üî HTTP)
  • Handle authentication and credential management
  • Support connection pooling for performance optimization
  • Provide built-in retry mechanisms for transient failures

API Management

  • Enforces rate limiting and quotas
  • Supports API key and OAuth-based validation
  • Offers analytics and usage monitoring
  • Includes a developer portal for API discovery and onboarding

Event Mesh

  • Supports publish / subscribe messaging
  • Provides queue-based guaranteed delivery
  • Enables topic-based routing
  • Allows multiple subscribers to process events independently

7. Key Takeaways

Understanding System Capabilities

SAP ECC Strengths

  • Mature and stable RFC/BAPI framework
  • Robust IDoc infrastructure for asynchronous processing
  • Battle-tested reliability in enterprise landscapes
  • Rich Enterprise Services Repository

SAP S/4HANA Advantages

  • Native OData / REST APIs
  • Built-in event-driven integration
  • High performance powered by SAP HANA
  • CDS views for optimized data access
  • Includes everything ECC offers ‚Äî enhanced and modernized

SAP BTP Integration Suite as the Bridge

  • Centralized protocol translation
  • Secure cloud connectivity
  • End-to-end orchestration layer
  • Enterprise-grade monitoring and governance

Protocol Selection Guidance

  • RFC / BAPI: Synchronous transactions with immediate validation
  • IDoc: Bulk data processing with guaranteed delivery
  • OData: REST APIs for modern applications (S/4HANA only)
  • SOAP: Legacy enterprise web services
  • File Interfaces: Batch processing and data migrations
  • Events: Real-time, decoupled integration (S/4HANA)

Preparation Is Critical

  • System configuration must be completed before development
  • Security and authorizations must be production-ready
  • Network connectivity should be fully tested
  • Monitoring and alerting should be established early
